body: I should say that I create a `Client` and make a short get request frequently from many threads, so this timeout is frequently waited on and eventually seems to be triggered, but faster if the process is getting some of its threads paused by strace onto less.

I also ran into this problem under heavy load. 
The bad thing is that it just panics and crash my application:

```Rust
  wait::timeout(spawn_rx, Some(Duration::from_secs(5)))
            .expect("runtime thread cancelled")?;
```

Is it possible just return error, and not crash all world?

issue.title: Return an Error instead of panic if sync Client cannot startup runtime.

repository.name: reqwest
repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

issue.body:
The timeout is also increased to 10 seconds from 5.

Closes #392

body: There is no way to actually check if the error is this specific error, which means I can't add retry logic.
This is really annoying. A program should not fail just because you hit ctrl-z on it. And I shouldn't have to personally add retry logic.

@njaard 
> program should not fail just because you hit ctrl-z on

But what the difference between this timeout for you and network timeout?
Even without problem described in this issue you still get network timeout error after "ctrl+z",
or I missed something?

May be after resolution of #316 it would be possible to globally setup retry strategy,
but it is separate issue.
A network timeout is at least under my control, and it's something I would test explicitly for if I feel the need to.
Also, it's the request that fails in a network timeout, as opposed to the client builder.
Fair enough, I figured putting a timeout on waiting for the other thread to start would be useful in cases where that thread hangs, but perhaps not. I'll remove the timeout entirely.
